title: Understanding Human Error
content: Human error is not a root cause—it's a starting point for investigation. People don't come to work intending to fail. Errors emerge from conditions: poor design, inadequate training, time pressure, fatigue, ambiguous information. Understanding error requires understanding context.

mcq.question: An operator makes an error that causes an incident. What's the most useful question?

options.B: What conditions made this error possible or likely?
options.C: How do we discipline the operator?

mcq.explanation: Blaming the operator answers nothing useful and prevents recurrence. Understanding conditions—interface design, procedures, workload, supervision—reveals systemic factors that, if addressed, prevent future errors by anyone in similar conditions.

openQuestions: How does your organization investigate errors?
What conditions make errors more likely in your workplace?
